importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the crash, which occurred on September 18, 2025, is critical as it marks the event that led to the tragic loss of life and initiated a safety review of pilot communication protocols.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time of the article's publication reflects the most recent update on the NTSB preliminary report, indicating the current state of investigation and public awareness of the incident.

keyTakeAways: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina, along with two others.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) reported that the plane entered a 'tightening spiral' during flight, leading to the crash.
James had requested a visual approach to runway 7, which was approved by air traffic control, but failed to tune to the common traffic advisory frequency.
James announced his position at 6,800 feet and a planned 360-degree turn, but did not change the radio frequency, causing a breakdown in communication.
The NTSB found no mechanical issues with the Cirrus SR22T aircraft.

Brett James was a prominent songwriter who collaborated with major artists including Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, with notable success including co-writing 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' for Carrie Underwood.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James, 57, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina, while attempting a visual approach to runway 7. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) reported that the single-engine Cirrus SR22T entered a 'tightening spiral' after James failed to tune his radio to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF), despite being instructed to do so. He announced his position and a planned 360-degree turn, but no further communication occurred. The NTSB found no mechanical issues with the aircraft. James was a highly sought-after songwriter who collaborated with major artists including Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, with a breakthrough success in 2005 through co-writing 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' for Carrie Underwood.
